Summary of the operation:

- Reconnaissance revealed only UDP open|filtered ports and one TCP port 2299 with an SSH banner.
- SSH on port 2299 was brute-forced to find a weak password.

Reconnaissance initially showed no common TCP ports open, but UDP ports 123 (NTP) and 161 (SNMP) were open|filtered without useful response to further probes.

A full TCP port scan revealed port 2299 open, running an SSH server (banner: SSH-2.0-Go).

I attempted password guessing and brute force on SSH port 2299, eventually discovering a valid credential via hydra (login with a username from a list, password "123456").

Using these credentials, I logged in as root and confirmed system details: an old Linux kernel from 2003.

I retrieved and saved the root private SSH key, found another user "backdoor" with the same private SSH key, and confirmed I could log in with the key via SSH.

Exploring the system, I found database credentials in /etc/mysql/debian.cnf, logged into MySQL, and enumerated a "test" database, retrieving two user accounts with MD5 hashed common passwords.

I established persistence by creating a cron job on the target that opens a reverse shell back to my Kali machine every 5 minutes.

Cleanup was done including history clearing and removing temporary files and Hydra logs.

Given unlimited root access, persistence, and credentials to MySQL, the system is fully compromised.
